trans-unit.source: . Note that Statsd clears all counter values every time it sends the metrics to Graphite, which usually happens every 10 seconds. If you need a persistent value, it may be more appropriate to use a gauge instead of a counter.
trans-unit.target: . Note that Statsd clears all counter values every time it sends the metrics to Graphite, which usually happens every 10 seconds. If you need a persistent value, it may be more appropriate to use a gauge instead of a counter.

trans-unit.source: A decorator or context manager with options.
trans-unit.target: A decorator or context manager with options.

trans-unit.source: Added ‘perfmetrics.tween’ and ‘perfmetrics.wsgi’ stats for measuring request timing and counts.
trans-unit.target: Added ‘perfmetrics.tween’ and ‘perfmetrics.wsgi’ stats for measuring request timing and counts.

trans-unit.source: Added an optional Pyramid tween and a similar WSGI filter app that sets up the Statsd client for each request.
trans-unit.target: Added an optional Pyramid tween and a similar WSGI filter app that sets up the Statsd client for each request.

trans-unit.source: Added the @MetricMod decorator, which changes the name of metrics in a given context. For example, “@MetricMod(‘xyz.%s’)” adds a prefix.
trans-unit.target: Added the @MetricMod decorator, which changes the name of metrics in a given context. For example, “@MetricMod(‘xyz.%s’)” adds a prefix.

trans-unit.source: Because Graphite computes mean values implicitly, the most sensible way to treat counters in Graphite is as a “hits per second” value. That way, a graph can produce correct results no matter which resolution level it uses.
trans-unit.target: Because Graphite computes mean values implicitly, the most sensible way to treat counters in Graphite is as a “hits per second” value. That way, a graph can produce correct results no matter which resolution level it uses.

trans-unit.source: Detect if decorated method is class method or object method and behave accordingly.
trans-unit.target: Detect if decorated method is class method or object method and behave accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Graphite stores each metric as a time series with multiple resolutions. The sample graphite_buildout stores 10 second resolution for 48 hours, 1 hour resolution for 31 days, and 1 day resolution for 5 years. To produce a coarse grained value from a fine grained value, Graphite computes the mean value (average) for each time span.
trans-unit.target: Graphite stores each metric as a time series with multiple resolutions. The sample graphite_buildout stores 10 second resolution for 48 hours, 1 hour resolution for 31 days, and 1 day resolution for 5 years. To produce a coarse grained value from a fine grained value, Graphite computes the mean value (average) for each time span.

trans-unit.source: If perfmetrics sends packets too frequently, UDP packets may be lost and the application performance may be affected. You can reduce the number of packets and the CPU overhead using the

trans-unit.source: If you run that code, it will fire 2000 UDP packets at port 8125. However, unless you have already installed Graphite and Statsd, all of those packets will be ignored and dropped. Dropping is a good thing: you don’t want your production application to fail or slow down just because your performance monitoring system is stopped or not working.
trans-unit.target: If you run that code, it will fire 2000 UDP packets at port 8125. However, unless you have already installed Graphite and Statsd, all of those packets will be ignored and dropped. Dropping is a good thing: you don’t want your production application to fail or slow down just because your performance monitoring system is stopped or not working.

trans-unit.source: If you want your graph to show 1000 hits rather than 100 hits per second, apply the Graphite
trans-unit.target: If you want your graph to show 1000 hits rather than 100 hits per second, apply the Graphite

trans-unit.source: Install Graphite and Statsd to receive and graph the metrics. One good way to install them is the graphite_buildout example at github, which installs Graphite and Statsd in a custom location without root access.
trans-unit.target: Install Graphite and Statsd to receive and graph the metrics. One good way to install them is the graphite_buildout example at github, which installs Graphite and Statsd in a custom location without root access.

trans-unit.source: It usually makes sense to treat null values in Graphite as zero, though that is not the default; by default, Graphite draws nothing for null values. You can turn on that option for each graph.
trans-unit.target: It usually makes sense to treat null values in Graphite as zero, though that is not the default; by default, Graphite draws nothing for null values. You can turn on that option for each graph.

trans-unit.source: Made the signature of StatsdClient more like James Socol’s StatsClient.
trans-unit.target: Made the signature of StatsdClient more like James Socol’s StatsClient.

trans-unit.source: Metric can now be used as either a decorator or a context manager.
trans-unit.target: Metric can now be used as either a decorator or a context manager.

trans-unit.source: Next, tell perfmetrics how to connect to Statsd. (Until you do, the decorators have no effect.) Ideally, either your application should read the Statsd URI from a configuration file at startup time, or you should set the STATSD_URI environment variable. The example below uses a hard-coded URI:
trans-unit.target: Next, tell perfmetrics how to connect to Statsd. (Until you do, the decorators have no effect.) trans-unit.source: The perfmetrics package is a client of the Statsd daemon by Etsy, which is in turn a client of Graphite (specifically, the Carbon daemon). Because the perfmetrics package sends UDP packets to Statsd, perfmetrics adds no I/O delays to applications and little CPU overhead. It can work equally well in threaded (synchronous) or event-driven (asynchronous) software.
trans-unit.target: The perfmetrics package is a client of the Statsd daemon by Etsy, which is in turn a client of Graphite (specifically, the Carbon daemon). Because the perfmetrics package sends UDP packets to Statsd, perfmetrics adds no I/O delays to applications and little CPU overhead. It can work equally well in threaded (synchronous) or event-driven (asynchronous) software.

trans-unit.source: The perfmetrics package provides a simple way to add software performance metrics to Python libraries and applications. Use perfmetrics to find the true bottlenecks in a production application.
trans-unit.target: The perfmetrics package provides a simple way to add software performance metrics to Python libraries and applications. Use perfmetrics to find the true bottlenecks in a production application.

trans-unit.source: Timing metrics produced by “@metric”, “@metricmethod”, and “@Metric” now have a “.t” suffix by default to avoid naming conflicts.
trans-unit.target: Timing metrics produced by “@metric”, “@metricmethod”, and “@Metric” now have a “.t” suffix by default to avoid naming conflicts.

trans-unit.source: Treating counters as hits per second has unfortunate consequences, however. If some metric sees a 1000 hit spike in one second, then falls to zero for at least 9 seconds, the Graphite chart for that metric will show a spike of 100, not 1000, since Graphite receives metrics every 10 seconds and the spike looks to Graphite like 100 hits per second over a 10 second period.
trans-unit.target: Treating counters as hits per second has unfortunate consequences, however. If some metric sees a 1000 hit spike in one second, then falls to zero for at least 9 seconds, the Graphite chart for that metric will show a spike of 100, not 1000, since Graphite receives metrics every 10 seconds and the spike looks to Graphite like 100 hits per second over a 10 second period.

trans-unit.source: function, using a resolution of 10 seconds or more. The hitcount function converts per-second values to approximate raw hit counts. Be sure to provide a resolution value large enough to be represented by at least one pixel width on the resulting graph, otherwise Graphite will compute averages of hit counts and produce a confusing graph.
trans-unit.target: function, using a resolution of 10 seconds or more. The hitcount function converts per-second values to approximate raw hit counts. Be sure to provide a resolution value large enough to be represented by at least one pixel width on the resulting graph, otherwise Graphite will compute averages of hit counts and produce a confusing graph.
